fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
Earlier this week Stef and I were working on the monad container distributive law project. We had a very insightful meeting with Dan Marsden who mentioned (among other things) that we should look for applications for our characterisation. Things to try:
Find characterisations for tighter classes of monad containers (i.e. commutative, affine, relevant) and see if this simplifies the distributive law. We have already characterised distributive laws for cartesian monad containers for example.
Prove more than just mere existence of distributive laws - use the characterisation to find exactly how many there are for a given pair of monad containers.
Over-approximate distributive law requirements to have an easier time with the above. For example, we could consider when the position map v is just \langle \pi _2 , \pi _1 \rangle , which often seems to be the case in simpler examples.
Find which algebraic theories correspond to container monads, to tie our work to Maaike Zwart and Dan's work on distributive laws for algebraic theories.

This morning and yesterday evening I was trying to work out what monad containers correspond to algebraic theories. Since algebraic theories interpret finitary monads, I first worked out when monad containers are finitary; lemma 1.7.3 from Joachim Kock's "Notes on Polynomial Functors" shows that this is exactly when the position sets are finite.

By considering the algebras for a monad conatiner, it became pretty clear that the algebraic theory corresponding to a monad container essentially has an operation for each shape which interact in accordance with the monad container equalities.
  267lsd-0019lsd-0019.xmlMonad container algebrasDefinition2024129Chris Purdy
An algebra for a monad container (S \triangleright  P, \iota , \sigma , \text {pr}) is a pair (A, \alpha ) of a set A and a map \alpha  : \prod _{s : S} (P\ s \to  A) \to  A, satisfying:
       \begin {align*}       \alpha \ \iota \ (\lambda  \_ . a) &= a\\       \alpha \ (\sigma \ s\ f)\ (g \circ  \text {pr}) &= \alpha \ s\ (\lambda  p . \alpha \ (f\ p)\ (g\ p))      \end {align*}   
  269lsd-0020lsd-0020.xmlAlgebraic theories for cartesian monad containersProposition2024129Chris Purdy
The Set-functor interpretation of a finitary cartesian monad container (S \triangleright  P, \iota , \sigma ) is the same as that of the algebraic theory consisting of an operation \oplus _s with arity n \cong  P\ s for each s : S, and the following equations:
       \begin {align*}       \oplus _\iota \ (\oplus _s\ \vec {t}) &= \oplus _s\ \vec {t}\\       \oplus _s\ (\oplus _\iota \ t_1)\ \dots \ (\oplus _\iota \ t_n) &= \oplus _s\ t_1\ \dots \ t_n\\       \oplus _s\ (\oplus _{f(1)}\ \vec {t_1})\ \dots \ (\oplus _{f(n)}\ \vec {t_n}) &= \oplus _{(\sigma \ s\ f)}\ \vec {t_1}\ \dots \ \vec {t_n}     \end {align*}   
  I'm only considering cartesian monad containers for now, since their algebraic theories were much easier to describe - I'm not exactly sure how to phrase the equations in the non-cartesian case. For example, \oplus _\iota  is not necessarily unary in that case, and \oplus _{(\sigma \ s\ f)} may have fewer arguments than the sum of the arities of each \oplus _{f(i)} - the resulting equations feel rather unnatural.
I think [gambinokock2013] describes all of this in a more general form. A good reference describing filtered colimits is the Stacks project.

An aside: I also found this presentation by Steve Awodey that describes the link between polynomial functors/monads and models of type theory, which probably links closely to the concept of \Sigma -universes.

fr:title.text: All affine monad containers are representable

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: All affine monad containers are representable

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let (S \triangleright P, \iota , \sigma , \text {pr}) be a commutative monad container. By taking the categorical definition of affine monads and specialising it to monad container extensions, we get for all a, b : S the equation: \sigma \ a\ (\lambda \_ . b) = a Since we have a point \iota : S, we can conclude that S is contractible. Hence we have that S \triangleright P is 1 \triangleright \lambda \_ . P\ \iota .

Let (S \triangleright P, \iota , \sigma , \text {pr}) be a monad container. We call the monad container commutative when the following laws hold: \begin {align*} \sigma \ a\ (\lambda \_ . b) &= \sigma \ b\ (\lambda \_ . a)\\ \text {pr}_1\ p &= \text {pr}_2\ p\\ \text {pr}_2\ p &= \text {pr}_1\ p \end {align*} The laws for \text {pr} hold given the first law. Commutative monad containers interpret exactly the commutative monads (w.r.t. cartesian product) for container functors.
I was previously using Obsidian for my research diary, but I found it a little heavyweight for what I was using it for: weekly (or fortnightly) notes on what I've been thinking about.

Being able to "transclude" trees into other ones is another reason why I'm using Forester for this. Writing definitions once and then including them as many times as needed seems far better than having to jump inbetween files.

  253lsd-0024lsd-0024.xmlRelation between container distributive laws and matching pairs of monoids/Zappa-SzÃ©p products20241211Chris Purdy
As mentioned in [ahmanuustalu2013], directed container distributive laws are generalisations of matching pairs of monoid actions. Further, composition of directed containers via a distributive law is a generalisation of the Zappa-SzÃ©p product of two monoids. As mentioned in the paper, you can actually recover the definition of a matching pair by looking at distributive laws between representable directed containers.255lsd-0025lsd-0025.xmlDirected container distributive law between representables20241211Chris Purdy
Let (1 \triangleright  \lambda  \_ . A, \downarrow ^A, o^A, \oplus ^A) and (1 \triangleright  \lambda  \_ . B, \downarrow ^B, o^B, \oplus ^B) be representable directed containers. By specialising the equations of a directed container distributive law to these, all equations involving u_2 disappear and we are left with:
       \begin {align*}       v_1\ b\ o^A &= o^A\\       v_1\ o^B\ a &= a\\       v_1\ b\ (a \oplus ^A a') &= v_1\ b\ a \oplus ^A v_1\ (v_2\ b\ a)\ a'\\       v_1\ (b \oplus ^B b')\ a &= v_1\ b\ (v_1\ b'\ a)\\       v_2\ b\ o^A &= b\\       v_2\ o^B\ a &= o^B\\       v_2\ b\ (a \oplus ^A a') &= v_2\ (v_2\ b\ a)\ a'\\       v_2\ (b \oplus ^B b')\ a &= v_2\ b\ (v_1\ b' a) \oplus ^B v_2\ b'\ a     \end {align*}   
  which exhibit v_1 and v_2 as a matching pair of monoid maps between the monoids (A , o^A, \oplus ^A) and (B, o^B, \oplus ^B). Hence, directed container distributive laws of this type are in bijection with matching pairs of the relevant monoids.
As it turns out, monad container distributive laws are also a generalisation of matching pairs of monoid actions. This is a bit harder to see than in the directed container case, but as before we can recover the data and equations for a matching pair by specialising the distributive law to a particular type of monad container.257lsd-0026lsd-0026.xmlMonad container distributive law between writers20241211Chris Purdy
Let (A \triangleright  \lambda  \_ . 1, \iota ^A, \sigma ^A, \text {pr}^A) and (B \triangleright  \lambda  \_ . 1, \iota ^B, \sigma ^B, \text {pr}^B) be monad containers. By specialising the data and equations for a monad container distributive law to these, v_1 and v_2 become trivial (\text {pr}^A and \text {pr}^B are already trivial), and we are left with:
  
       \begin {align*}            u_1\ \iota ^A\ (\lambda  \_ . b) &= b\\     u_1\ a\ (\lambda  \_ . \iota ^B) &= \iota ^B\\     u_1\ (\sigma ^A\ a\ (\lambda  \_ . a'))\ (\lambda  \_ . b) &= u_1\ a\ (\lambda  \_ . u_1\ a'\ (\lambda  \_ . b))\\     u_1\ a\ (\lambda  \_ . \sigma ^B\ b\ (\lambda  \_ . b')) &= \sigma ^B\ (u_1\ a\ (\lambda  \_ . b))\ (\lambda  \_ . u_1\ (u_2\ a\ (\lambda  \_ . b)\ *)\ (\lambda  \_ . b'))\\      u_2\ \iota ^A\ (\lambda  \_ . b)\ * &= \iota ^A\\     u_2\ a\ (\lambda  \_ . \iota ^B)\ * &= a\\     u_2\ (\sigma ^A\ a\ (\lambda  \_ . a'))\ (\lambda  \_ . b)\ * &= \sigma ^A\ (u_2\ a\ (\lambda  \_ . u_1\ a'\ (\lambda  \_ . b))\ *)\ (\lambda  \_ . u_2\ a'\ (\lambda  \_ . b')\ *)\\     u_2\ a\ (\lambda  \_ . \sigma ^B\ b\ (\lambda  \_ . b'))\ * &= u_2\ (u_2\ a\ (\lambda  \_ . b)\ *)\ (\lambda  \_ . b')\ *        \end {align*}   

  Bear in mind that, since all position sets are 1, we do not lose generality by assuming constant all of the functions in the equations above. By defining:
  
       \begin {align*}            \alpha \ a\ b := u_1\ a\ (\lambda  \_ . b)\\     \beta \ a\ b := u_2\ a\ (\lambda  \_ . b)\ *\\     a \otimes ^A a' := \sigma ^A\ a\ (\lambda  \_ . a')\\     b \otimes ^B b' := \sigma ^B\ b\ (\lambda  \_ . b')        \end {align*}   

  we can rewrite these equations as:
  
       \begin {align*}            \alpha \ \iota ^A\ b &= b\\     \alpha \ a\ \iota ^B &= \iota ^B\\     \alpha \ (a \otimes ^A a')\ b &= \alpha \ a\ (\alpha \ a'\ b)\\     \alpha \ a\ (b \otimes ^B b') &= (\alpha \ a\ b) \otimes ^B (\alpha \ (\beta \ a\ b)\ b')\\      \beta \ \iota ^A\ b &= \iota ^A\\     \beta \ a\ \iota ^B &= a\\     \beta \ (a \otimes ^A a')\ b &= (\beta \ a\ (\alpha \ a'\ b)) \otimes ^A (\beta \ a'\ b')\\     \beta \ a\ (b \otimes ^B b') &= \beta \ (\beta \ a\ b)\ b'        \end {align*}   

  These are exactly the equations exhibiting \alpha  and \beta  as a matching pair of monoid actions between (A, \otimes ^A, \iota ^A) and (B , \otimes ^B, \iota ^B). Therefore, monad container distributive laws of this type are in bijection with matching pairs of the relevant monoids.
As shown, both of these types of distributive law are generalisations of matching pairs of monoid actions, each in a slightly different way. For directed containers the generalisation is "in the direction of the shapes", and for monad containers the generalisation is "in the direction of the positions".
